author: Rude_Ad_1095
lucky_pierre
body:
SQ - down 21% 52 week high (193 vs 154)

GPN - down 25% 52 week high  (209 vs 157)

FISV down 24% 52 week high (125 vs 95)

FIS down 22% 52 week high (158 vs 124)

PYPL down 14% 52 week high (215 vs 186)

These are the big players in the payments market and are highly correlated due to a lack of real differentiation in their overall products. SQ doesn't do anything particularly special compared to anyone else TBH (their product was easier to use years ago but the others have caught up). 

SQ also is running at negative earnings compared to their competitors, in a year where merchants who aren't Amazon have questionable revenue streams, and SQ is mostly dependent on merchant acquiring and volume which simply isn't there with small merchants shuttering due to the pandemic. Recent SQ drops seem more like a facing reality situation instead of some other fundamental issue. If you are more interested in tech payments PYPL is probably the way to go but what do I know.

author: Rude_Ad_1095
body:
Since I fuck wit u bro lemme give u some good DD on DG 

\*\*DG\*\* 

Has not had a single year where store openings has gone down. In fact, just opened their 17,000th store, last year they had 15,400 stores or some shit.

Has not had a single year, quarter, where same store sales have been down. in fact coronavirus has made shoppers more cost-caring and going to these dicount store (DG is NOT a dollar store, like DLTR, they're more like a cheaper WMT)

I'm betting they hit $230 after earnings, also IV is very low on some of these options as if earnings isn't happening. very interesting, i expect a bigger move into earnings. 

\*\*AES\*\*

nothing much here. its a very diverse company that supplies energy in places like Argentina, Brazil, and also the US and Europe. They struggled from currency devaluations but recently set up contracts to make all payments in dollar-denominated amounts 

only other piece of info is they'd probably do well under biden administration, they are shifting away from coal and gas and moving to solar and wind. and especially being able to store this energy in batteries for when its dry or dark out.

Lastly, and probably the most important thing for AES, is just like FISV, someone has been buying calls and executing them and rolling them out. Ex. Last sept/oct they bought a shitton of 19calls, those went ITM. now they have 22calls (22,000 OI/volume)

author: plasticblock4dayz
body:
Tech valuations are pricing in exponential growth in the future in perpetuity. I’m not saying it will decline, but if you’re trading at 50x revenue, there needs to be growth to justify that multiple. If there is no growth, then 50x P/S is absolutely absurd. 

Imo Square is overhyped because of cash app. FISV has more growth and out does SQ in every main business line. FISV gets no attention because it’s not a meme, even though it’s a way better company fundamentally.  I know you can point to digital currencies as what makes SQ better, but underneath the hood of digital currencies is one of the largest Ponzi Schemes in history run by Bitfinex/Tether. Square is unknowingly (I hope) helping funnel government backed currency into funny money that could all be gone when authorities find a way to prosecute Bitfinex/Tether for fraud. Right now the “outside your jurisdiction” defense works, but it won’t work forever. 

5G is just a marginal improvement over 4G networks. It’s an expected improvement, nothing revolutionary at all. At this point, the “5G revolution” is just marketing.  Qualcomm won’t go away of course, it’s just expected. Similar hype was around Qualcomm during the dotcom bubble, but investors eventually realized telecom networks are fairly low margin and can’t justify high multiples. 

We’re really coming full circle with the tech bubble. Tech won’t go away, but the big tech companies in the future may not be the same ones we have today.

author: SportsDogsDollars
body:
Trading commission is a drag with small amounts, but you also have a lot of time so I'd recommend going with high risk aka also higher volatility, and generally higher return ETFs. 

You will get free trades /no buying comission by using Questrade so that's a plus. 

Look for tech heavy ETFs or growth area ETFs. Where a lot of those companies are US based you could get a "hedged" ETF to mitigate currency risk. 

ZQQ is a currency hedged Nasdaq 100 ETF. Ie very tech heavy. 

I also like IPAY, it's an ETF focused on digital payment transactions. Ie a growing area globally, but also has a couple blue chips like visa, MasterCard, fiserv. 

25 now, but I wish I had of pumped all my cash into a Nasdaq 100 ETF as I started investing (I was ~17).

author: thewimsey
body:
No, it's not sketchy because money is involved.

The key to Bill Gates being successful wasn't that his mother knew some guy at IBM; it was that his wealthy family sent him to an expensive private school where he both met Paul Allen *and* learned about computers.  Gates's mom served on a charitable board with the CEO of IBM; they were more associates than friends, and that wouldn't have helped Gates at all if he hadn't already, you know, founded MS. 

Elon's family didn't own an emerald mine, and he was $100k in debt when he graduated college. 

Meritocracy just means that merit - mostly in the sense of skills - is rewarded. It doesn't mean that everyone necessarily has an equal chance. 

If a company needs and engineer and I have an engineering degree, and you don't - maybe because you had an abusive family growing up wit a father in prison and so never graduated from HS, the company is hiring me *on merit*. I'm an engineer; you're not; you can't do the job. 

This doesn't mean that if our lives were switched at age 3 I would have done any better; that's just a separate question from meritocracy. 

I mean, if a company needs someone who speaks French, and my wealthy family summered in France every year and sent me there one a gap year and then on a junior year abroad...while you took French in HS...merit means I get the job *even though* I was only able to obtain my qualifications because my family was rich enough to keep sending me to France. 

But the company isn't hiring me because of who I am, but because of what I can do, and that I can do it better than you can.

author: LucisMensEtManus
body:
You have a number of comments on your financial model, so I won't comment there.

To me, what is missing is the story. First, comparison to the Leidos, CACI, BAH, IBM, HPE etc. of the government consulting world. They too employ a lot of talent. What is the difference with PLTR? Second, government consulting is often a "customer intimate" model, not quality leadership. Govt says it wants high tech, but they often buy those companies who understand them most. Which model is PLTR using? Why will PLTR succeed in Govt? Is it primarily IC?

Third, if PLTR has silicon valley magic in it, then why is the commercial business not taking off? If you have a superior value proposition, that will be reflected in high margins and a kind of inevitability of customers who are drawn to your products. A weakness there would make me pause.

author: 3000dollarsuitCOMEON
body:
Competition, brand deterioration, and forced breakups by government action. 

No company is invulnerable given time. Standard Oil in the early 1900s, IBM when mainframes were everything. Capital is so cheap right now that it's easy for startups to get funds. It may not seem like it but consumers will switch for better products or ways of doing things. Brands don't last forever and companies become more and more difficult to manage as their size increases.

Also don't forget the world is much bigger than just the US. China and other large developed countries are full of brilliant people, lots of access to capital. How long until Alibaba has boots on the ground in USA and starts aggressively pressuring Amazon?

My guess is that eventually the government will put a stop to big tech simply buying out their competitors. It's already a bipartisan talking point.

author: audion00ba
body:
I can't even say whether this is sarcasm or not. You mean the IBM Power10 processor? 

The only thing that's sort of interesting is the "Distributed Memory Disaggregation and Sharing"-feature, but that processor is not available until the end of 2021. If there is any proof that it is *real* and is competitive in terms of pricing, then I might see some value there. 

The world has been moving to commodity servers for the past 15 years. IBM is everything but that. 

IBM has a debt of 50B. I don't see how their current assets are worth more than their debt.

author: diesel408
body: So the other response summed it up pretty well, but left one other important factor out. The importance of Intel's architecture is fading. It will always be around of course, but anyone that doesn't think ARM is going to keep getting a larger and larger bite of the pie isn't paying attention. Apple will give everyone permission to target software for ARM architecture and we'll soon see a second attempt from Microsoft. Again, we'll always have applications for Intel, but it won't be nearly as dominant. Intel's production woes over the past half decade are well documented, and it's clear that they are about as well run as Boeing these days. The problem for Intel is that they face much more fierce competition than Boeing. Intel will survive of course, but they'll be a shell of their former self, and they'll have fumbled their flagship products and missed the boat on the areas of the industry that are sure to see rapid growth. I understand that people want to target value, but Intel is priced the way they are for good reason. If you're looking for value in Intel then I have some IBM stock to sell you as well.

author: lucidvein
body:
I would not recommend buying IBM at this time.  It's a company to watch with the restructuring changes, but they are restructuring to stay afloat.  They didn't adapt with the times and have been completely bypassed when it comes to cloud offerings etc.  

They did buy redhat which is likely a good investment, but the stock has been tracking downward for quite some time.  I'd absolutely wait dipping your foot in until they manage to turn their actual stock performance around as it's a stock continuing to experience negative momentum in a very bullish tech sector.

author: kotsumu
body:
They have small competitors here and there, mostly small scale startups. Closest ones worth mentioning that I can think of and are not mainstream companies like IBM are companies like Leidos and Booz Allen Hamilton.

The way their business model works is fundamentally different from Palantir. They evaluate technologies and purchase/ contracts from smaller companies (maybe startups) and package it up as a complete solution and sell it to the government. This essentially means that these companies are a little more than resellers of tech. Palantir's direct to consumer model focus their investments in RnD.

author: abcomputer
body: IBM cloud?

author: Vast_Cricket
body:
**Spce** is legit. Keep in mind that is a rocket science company. Suppose gov't did not give the clearance for 2 years we understand they are ready can wait for 2 years.  So I will be around so long there are investors willing to keep the company running.

As for the eV controversial giant, this is not quite finished. Personally even if they have no product or schedule they will linger around awhile. They can use their patents sue every manufacturer in eV and often they generate revenue from those manufacturers as hush up money.

Some years ago, a hard disk manufacturer making 3.5" hard drive business was failing. It had a strong intellectual property department sued every hard disk manufacturer in the 3.5" drive claiming patient infringement. In 1990 IBM was hit with a lawsuit as an inventor of the drive and sue by a smaller player. It paid some hush money. Seagate was dismissed in 1997, sue again and paid [$45 M to R+ as late as 2000](https://www.electronicsweekly.com/news/archived/resources-archived/seagate-to-pay-rodime-45m-to-settle-suit-2000-01/).   R+ only exists as a shell company and its share price soared on news of the patent settlement.  I think **NKLA** can remain as a shell company with its patent portfolio covering designs that covers most vehicles built electric or not. [It sue Tsla earlier](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanohnsman/2020/04/20/teslas-effort-to-short-circuit-nikola-lawsuit-fizzles-as-patent-office-denies-door-argument/?sh=44dc21a45d78). That Tesla copied NKLA on shield, cab shape and windshield design sued for $2B. If you think you will prosper you can bag hold your stocks.

body:

Candidates i have for next week are still Tesla, NVDA, IBM, NFLX

Nvidia would be a good hold it for a while stock, just in my eyes they seem to be heading the route of IBM, going more into the commercial business (cloud storage, servers...)  which will cause an initial drop in stock

author: peter-doubt
body:
Have you collected (not cashed) the checks? 

Are you the executor ( or she?)

Copy them .  Send the copy back to their investor relations dept., explaining the predicament.

IBM doesn't want it, and doing so defines the nightmare *they* have.. sending you reports every year at $20  plus administering your unwanted account.. you don't want it, nor do they! 

I'd start there. If you had the certificate, selling costs money, too. I'd find a charity and give it away for the deduction.

author: Summebride
body: I'd discourage hyperbole like "longer than your lifetime".  Statements like,that haven't aged well for Xerox, Commodore, IBM, GE, Blackberry, Enron, Exxon, Blockbuster, and more.

author: FifiandColumbo
body:
They let her cash/deposit checks without his signature for a few months after he passed away, but it's been a year and a half, and now they're telling her any checks need to be in her name.  She's a sweet little old lady, though, so maybe she can sweet talk them into it. 

Calling IR at IBM is worth a try. Thanks for the suggestion.

author: Fractadactyl
body: Ibm dip

author: ReflectAA
body:
Why can’t your mom cash your dads checks? That is the most unusual part of this. Were they never married? It might be easier to bring his death certificate to a bank and explain the situation and see if they allow her to cash his checks as the surviving spouse. 

I would not bother with the Compushare BS. If the bank doesn’t work you can try contacting IR directly for IBM and tell them that Compushare is being intentionally difficult. I’ve never tried that myself though it may lead nowhere.

author: djpitagora
body: IBM, Apple and Microsoft disagree.

author: 036Gooddaysir036
body: IBM is also an excellent buy. It just recently became an Aristocrat since it increased its dividend for 25 years now. So both, both is good. But if you're only considering one or the other then it is going to come down to which you believe has a better business model and is more likely to continue to increase their dividend payout.

author: thewimsey
body:
MSFT wasn't  a computer company. It was a software company. IBM was a computer company.

The brilliance of MSFT was in - and this seems weird today - realizing that a company could make money just selling software. A ton of money. More money than computer makers could make by themselves. This was a kind of radical idea at the time.

Jobs was very successful at the computer business; the Apple was the bestselling PC from 1977-1982.

Apple wasn't killed by MSFT, it was killed by IBM, which built a PC from more or less off the shelf parts allowing *anyone* to build a clone. (Which, incidentally, would run windows). 

Apple's computers couldn't compete with PCs built with off the shelf parts. It's not about Jobs being bad; it's about other people being better.

IBM's approach almost immediately priced *them* out of the PC market, leaving the profits to MSFT and intel (and a tiny bit for clone makers, who mostly ended up in a low margin commodity business).

author: lucky_ducker
body: IBM used to be the classic "widows and orphans" stock. New stockbrokers were told that they could never lose their jobs by losing clients' money in IBM.

author: Lie-Minimum
body: IBM and INTC

author: DarkStarOptions
body:
>It does limit your loss by a half, but it does increase your probability of loss by a factor of two as well. Now that you close the spread once it gets touched, your probability of loss is now the probability of touching the short strike (which is approximately twice the probability of being ITM).

As opposed to waiting to see if the stock rebounds off the short strike?  

Makes sense.

&#x200B;

I opened a spread against IBM about 3 weeks ago, a 35 day spread.  It initially dipped below the short strike but I didn't freak out because I had 30 days for it to go back up....and it did.  Now my spread is OTM and profitable and has been for about a week.  

&#x200B;

This guy was putting forth a strategy of writing a spread with a short strike of 20 delta for < 14 days.  I guess the thought is if the stock moved that much in a short amount of time to test the short strike, probably best to just close it for a loss rather than manage it with just a few days left until expiration.  That's my guess but I don't know because I didn't ask him.

author: TheGoodBunny
body: Define "safest" and "long term" for yourself. No single company is safe forever. 10-15 years ago you would have picked Ford, IBM, Exxon as "safest for long term". For buy-and-forget you will be better off investing in an index.

author: ascendtofutility
body: It could happen over a period of five years or so. Yes it's unlikely. How likely was it for the Lehman bros and bear Stearns to collapse? How likely was it for IBM to fuck up and get knocked off the top? What I'm trying to say, there's more risk indexing right now than there ever was. My personal opinion, we are in a coronavirus bubble that will pop in a year or so when people can allocate money to other equities safely. Money doesn't disappear, it just moves around.

author: Kashm11r
body: BAM, FB, GOOG, IBM all have multi billion dollar investments in India. Major energy companies like Sunpower, First Solar, Canadian Solar, GE, Vestas as well.

author: skilliard7
body:
> Bitcoin has plenty of intrinsic use. These include borderless transfer without needing to convert to to local currency (cant do this with Western Union), black markets, safe haven from oppressive governments, sending aid to citizens of oppressive governments, ways to bypass import sanctions (see Iran), and more. Just because you don't have intrinsic use for BTC, doesn't mean others don't (see link below).

You can do this with Ethereum, Litecoin, Monero, Vertcoin, even Dogecoin. I agree cryptocurrency and blockchains are useful but I don't see Bitcoin as a long term store of value. It's far more volatile than precious metals and also intangible.

IBM is making huge strides towards quantum computing, and once they pull it off, Bitcoin will become worthless once the public/private key cryptography is cracked and anyone with access to a quantum computer can simply sign transactions to send coins to themselves. We're easily within 10 years at this point, possibly less.

>This is like saying anyone can create a better social network than Facebook and therefore Facebook has no value

What about Myspace? It came first.

>Wrong. Best case scenario is that BTC continues to be added to the balance sheets of large, publicly traded companies

Like 1 or 2 companies that hold it as a tiny position. I think Overstock and Square? Most companies that accept it just use Bitpay or Coinbase to instantly sell it.

author: dampon
body:
You know that decades ago that GE, Kodak, Xerox, IBM, Sears, etc. were the Amazons of those time periods right?

How are they doing today?

Can't use hindsight to pick a stock. And you can't assume just because Amazon is on top now it will continue to be forever.
